subject: RE: [junit] debuggers
msgSnippet: Good observation about using deduction to locate points of failure. Not to be picky, I tend to view statements about the possibility of never needing to trace
messageBody:
Good observation about using deduction to locate points of failure. Not
to be picky, I tend to view statements about the possibility of never
needing to trace code based on small scale examples, as similar to
concluding that you don't need sight to drive on highways because of
success traversing one's driveway with one's eyes closed. I agree with
Steven below that the strategy you take depends on your context.
Fine-grained test cases may reduce the need for tracing code with
debuggers but with any sufficiently complex application, especially one
that interacts with questionably documented 3rd party or system APIs, a
debugger will at some point become invaluable in determining the cause
of failure.

-----------------------------
Mike Silverstein
SilverMark, Inc.
The Object Testing Company
www.javatesting.com

> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>
> I completed my first professional Ruby project a week ago. It
> was nothing big: three weeks of Saturdays -- but it was my
> first professional project with a dynamically-typed language
> with no type checker. This caused me some problems, just
> because I'm not used to it. I usually say, "The compiler just
> stops me from making mistakes that I don't make anyway." I
> suppose that's not quite right for me.
>
> Anyhow, that's just a lead-in to my comment. In many cases, I
> would have either an unexpected 'nil' value, or an object
> that doesn't understand an expected message. My first
> instinct is to get in there with "p this" and "p that"...
> then I thought of this: if I have a 'nil' object over here,
> then there must be a bug over there... and when I started
> writing tests checking that results are non-nil over there, I
> no longer needed to trace my code.
>
> I'm still learning.
>
> So said steven.hale@... on 3/13/2003 --------------------
>
> My debugging habits are usually something like this:
>
> 1. Read the error message (if there is one)
> 2. Think
> 3. Read the log
> 4. Think
> 5. Write a unit test
> 6. Launch the debugger
>
> Since adopting junit (2 -3 years ago) I can honestly say I've
> not yet been forced down to level 6! I try to encourage
> programmers in my team not to start at 6 first.
>
> Judging by the varied responses there's clearly a whole range
> of other successful strategies - maybe it's related to the
> type of application being programmed.
>
> Steven
>
